Does there exist a library / plugin that would try something like push_neg - use X - decide line and internally simply generate simple SAT solver code?
(It could be something like a bot simply trying this out in the background and reporting if that works)

If you want to use SAT solvers on Bool goals you can use bv_decide:

example {x y z : Bool} (h1 : (x && y) = z) (h2 : x = !y) (h3 : z = true) : False := by bv_decide

I don't quite understand what kind of goals your specific pattern is targeting, do you have an example where bv_decide would not be applicable?

I've never used bv_decide, so I need to try it out first. But this is good :heart: . Thank you!

My use case is agentic and collaborative proof writing -- ie. getting to deep insights through aggressive context generation, and then having hundreds of bots working on well-defined, smaller tasks in the background. Wrote an article about this: https://buildermath.substack.com/p/on-math-platform
Btw. I built a small tool on top of Vampire in order to adjust operation tables (related to magma implications), and found it useful, but not strong enough. My approach is through SW/ML and deep/targeted math insights, so I'd prefer to double down on Lean4 / Mathlib4, and improve my Lean4 / Mathlib4 skills.
Btw. sorry for the typos.

For the reference: https://lean-lang.org/blog/2024-10-3-lean-4120/

Checked it out -- very interesting!
Michael Bucko has marked this topic as resolved.
I tested the ARM assembly popcount example, and that's supercool. But I guess I need to test it a number of times to really have a feel for it.
@Henrik Böving I just realized that the leansat repo got merged into lean4, and that's bv_decide. Thank you for mentioning that!

@Henrik Böving Since that tactic reduces goals to a SAT problem that is handled by an external SAT solver, perhaps there could also be agent_decide (assuming that the name is not taken).

One would write agent / by agent, and it'd internally use something like agent_decide. The agent would run something like this in a loop (well, C, not Python like in this case), and continuously adjust the TPTP file, collect the feedback from Vampire (or something else), learn, and repeat.

One could probably have something like this running in the bg. Perhaps even multiple instances of it.

Assuming that the near-term future of writing Lean is web or colab, one could imagine such workers running in the cloud, too.
